title: Short-Intensive Instructional Design Course for Scientific Inquiry in Game-Based Chemistry Education

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of secondary-level chemistry concepts (atomic structure, chemical bonding, chemical reactions) and basic instructional methods, comprehension of the scientific inquiry process (observation-hypothesis-experiment-analysis-conclusion)
context.additional_context: A course for pre-/in-service teachers to learn game-based chemistry lesson design and implementation in smartphone-based, resource-constrained environments. It emphasizes developing GBL (Game-Based Learning) activities integrating scientific inquiry elements and highlights low-cost, high-efficiency strategies applicable to real classrooms.

learning_goals: Design three game-based learning (GBL) activities effective for explaining chemical concepts, with each activity reflecting the scientific inquiry process (hypothesis setting–experiment–analysis–conclusion).
Compare two instructional strategies (variable control strategy, evidence-based feedback strategy) for enhancing cognitive and motivational effects when applying GBL.

Learners develop a one-week short-term lesson plan including three mobile-compatible quizzes (balancing chemical equations, periodic table puzzle, molecular structure assembly) and one science simulation (virtual experiment: measuring chemical reaction rates), and submit a lesson design document achieving at least 4 points per item (total ≥9/12) based on an in-house evaluation rubric (Content Suitability, Technical Accessibility, Learning Effectiveness).
Through project-based assessment, learners develop and present a GBL chemistry lesson model, demonstrating its scientific validity and educational effectiveness.

resources: Digital Resource Library for Chemistry Education
constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
